Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM/GOALI: Efficient Thermoelectricity with Low-cost Natural Minerals: a Synergistic Computational, Experimental, and Device Development Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Thermoelectric energy conversion allows for waste-heat recovery and it is an environmentally-friendly process; however, thermoelectric materials typically contain toxic elements. This aspect is problematic for large-scale applications and detracts from the benefits of using this technology. Therefore, finding ways to generate energy from non-toxic and low-cost materials is a high priority for thermoelectrics. This project seeks to develop methodologies for achieving high thermoelectric efficiency in systems composed of earth-abundant and environmentally safe elements. Advancing current fundamental understanding of such materials is beneficial in the development of effective strategies for enhanced thermoelectric properties. Device-related R&D towards prototype manufacturing helps move the thermoelectrics industry towards low cost processes. Results from this research may also be useful for solar cells and photovoltaics, since quaternary chalcogenides are also of interest in these fields.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: A major component of this project relies on the predictive power of computational and theoretical methods for materials design. The particular class of quaternary chalcogenides and related derivatives are targeted. Modeling and first principles calculations are directed towards understanding electronic structure features due to chemical and structural features, as well as nanostructuring, to control the transport in a beneficial way. In addition, state-of-the-art synthesis and characterization efforts serve as a benchmark for the proposed theory and as conceptual input for advancing the research further. The partnership with Marlow Industries, Inc., a world leader in commercial thermoelectrics applications, provides additional experimental capabilities for materials and device testing and facilitates work towards a prototype device whose commercial potential can also be evaluated. This synergistic project involves graduate students and it is especially suitable for the USF's PhD program in Applied Physics, the only such doctoral program in the state of Florida. Outreach activities and summer teaching modules for high school students are also a part of this project.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thermoelectricity is an environmentally-friendly technology for energy conversion which allows for waste-heat recovery and power generation without the use of fossil fuels. Thermoelectric materials, however, typically contain toxic elements and have large production and processing costs, which is problematic for large-scale applications and devices. In this project, we have investigated new, low-cost thermoelectric chalcogenide materials composed of earth-abundant constituents. Utilizing a synergistic approach, including experimental and computational efforts, we have advanced the fundamental understanding of such materials and disseminated new strategies for property optimization, low cost synthesis techniques and property optimization.

Quaternary chalcogenides and their derivatives are found to have low thermal conductivity, a key property for efficient thermoelectric conversion. In this project, we have synthesized phase-pure chalcogenides and measured their transport and thermoelectric properties. The synthetic techniques employed can be applied to other material systems. Utilizing state of the art first principles computational methods, systematic structure-property relations were established for the new chalcogenide materials we investigated, which were corroborated by our experimental results. The new physical mechanisms governing their transport properties constitute a major aspect of this study. Specifically, chalcogenides whose structures promote maximal electrostatic interaction between the electronic distributions of neighboring atoms will generally be characterized with low thermal conductivity. In addition, chalcogenides with atomic structures that contain characteristic deformations can display a polaronic-type transport, which substantially influences their thermal properties. This is quite atypical as such a transport is much more common in polymers and organic material systems. Moreover, we have demonstrated that the electrical and thermal properties of bulk composite materials composed of specific polymers and chalcogenide thermoelectric materials can be tuned, thereby allowing for optimization of the thermoelectric properties. For such composites, a unique transport mechanism associated with thermally induced tunneling governs the thermoelectric flow.  

The experimental techniques designed under this project, as well as the fundamental scientific knowledge developed from this work, can be translated to other chalcogenide systems. The transport mechanisms found here are closely related to the atomic structure of the materials in as much as they essentially possess internal anharmonicity, which in turn is responsible for the low thermal conductivity they possess. We also applied this general concept to materials with cage-like crystal structures; we were able to translate our work to the investigation of these materials as well. Filling the cages with loosely-bound atoms allows for the “rattling” of these atoms, which is associated with low thermal conductivity in these materials. Through ab initio simulations, routes for changing the transport by taking advantage of this rattling-type behavior in cage-like materials were revealed.

We have also found a new way to harness thermoelectric flow, where chalcogenides together with other classes of materials, can be utilized. This unique method relies on coordinate transformation mapping applied on thermoelectric transport equations from a thermodynamics perspective. This macroscopic approach is rather different than the atomistic simulations used to uncover governing processes associated with the materials internal lattice structure. This coordinate transformation method gives pathways of constructing metamaterials capable of cloaking, rotating, or concentrating thermoelectric flow in a desired direction. A strong benefit is the fact that this approach is general and does not depend on boundary conditions, geometry, inhomogeneity, or anisotropy factor. A procedure for designing metamaterial composites to control and redirect the thermoelectric flow to achieve cloaking, rotating, or concentrating effects was also developed, and can be applied to future experimental designs.

This research has been an excellent platform for training graduate students for future careers in science and industry. Graduate students involved in the experimental work have been trained in many aspects of the synthesis and characterization of novel materials for thermoelectric applications with an emphasis on an understanding of the structure-property relationships of new material systems in order to develop a comprehensive understanding of their physical properties. The effect of structural and chemical variations on the transport was the focus, and the knowledge learned can be applied to developing materials towards significant advancements in technological significant applications that the students will undertake in their career paths. Graduate students involved in the theoretical work have become proficient in modern computational techniques and analytical models, with a solid foundation to carry out research in other projects as future postdocs or work in industry. There have been significant outreach activities for this project, which have been directed toward high schools from the Tampa Bay area. A summer teaching model was developed and advertised to high school students and teachers to attract future STEM majors at the University of South Florida. The content of the model involved experiments, lectures, and problem solving sessions as well as research lab visits. These were all designed to introduce high school students to the field of physics through an exposure to actual research as well as better understanding of skills and requirements for academic success.
